Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Currently, no standard curriculum exists to prepare students for the profession of plumbing engineering design in two-year colleges. This project is filling the void by implementing the PIPED (Program in Plumbing Engineering Design) initiative. In this initiative, the American Society of Plumbing Engineers (ASPE) is developing: 1) collaborative partnerships with a community college, high schools, and plumbing engineering employers; 2) a national, standardized curriculum that can be a model for community colleges across the country; 3) a national certifying test and certificate for plumbing engineering design technicians; 4) plumbing engineering design books and calculating tools for PIPED; and 5) plumbing engineering lessons that can be integrated into high schools to increase STEM knowledge and increase visibility of plumbing engineering design. The materials are being implemented at community colleges. The PIPED curriculum and coursework incorporates basic science and math, engineering principles, and technical skills such as CAD and BIM (Building Information Modeling). Green concepts such as water conservation, solar energy, and geothermal heating are being integrated into the courses throughout the program for graduates to be adequately prepared for the increasing emphasis on sustainability and LEED certification. The broader impact of this project includes producing a model curriculum in plumbing engineering design that can be implemented in two-year colleges throughout the country and increasing the number of qualified engineering technicians to meet the workforce demand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Program in Plumbing Engineering Design (PIPED) was a collaborative initiative between City College of San Francisco (CCSF) and the American Society of Plumbing Engineers (ASPE). ASPE is an international organization dedicated to helping protect the public’s health and safety by educating and promoting the career growth of plumbing system designers and engineers. ASPE also works to ensure that our precious water resources are preserved and maintained.

This collaboration between academics and industry brought together experts on both sides to fulfill the primary goals of PIPED, which were: 1) to develop a national model curriculum that incorporated green and sustainable design elements and hands-on learning, along with related materials; and 2) to develop a national certification exam for technicians in plumbing system design.

Regarding the first goal, an Associate of Science degree in Mechanical Engineering Technology at the City College of San Francisco was reworked to include a focus on plumbing engineering design. The degree will be offered for the first time in the 2016–2017 school year. Students can specialize in either HVAC (heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning) or engineered plumbing systems. The curriculum includes three revised capstone classes in engineered plumbing systems, the reintroduction of an applied physics course, a technical mathematics course, and a computer-aided design (CAD) class specific to plumbing and HVAC systems. Field trips were added to the curriculum to help students experience real-world applications. 

To help in developing the degree, CCSF students were surveyed over five semesters regarding their opinion of the engineered plumbing design capstone courses, which helped indicate the most popular and sustaining courses. Their replies also suggested that hands-on learning and more sustainable design (green) techniques should be included.

A handbook, Advanced Plumbing Technology II, was revised to make updates and incorporate green design elements as part of the curriculum development project. This book is now being used as a textbook at CCSF. 

The number of students trended upward throughout the project, and the percentage of minority students exceeded the goal of 25% in every semester. The goal of 25% women was met in one of five semesters. Due to various delays, the curriculum has not yet been disseminated to other community colleges.

Regarding the second goal, a national certification exam, the Certified Plumbing Design Technician (CPDT) exam, was developed and standardized by ASPE subject matter experts using a job analysis. Those who pass the exam can use the CPDT designation, which is intended as a precursor to ASPE’s Certified in Plumbing Design (CPD) designation. The CPD designation requires at least eight years of industry experience, whereas the CPDT designation is intended for those in the early years of their career. To help candidates prepare for the exam, a revised CPD Review Manual was published, and a new CPDT Study Guide was developed.

The first CPDT exam was administered in November 2014, with 33 examinees taking the online test. In 2015, 44 examinees took the CPDT exam (a 33% increase). 

56 CPDT exam takers responded to a survey on the professional benefits of the CPDT credential (a 63% response rate). The survey indicated that 30% found the credential very beneficial, 59% found it somewhat beneficial, and 11% said it was not beneficial. Among those who said it was beneficial, 52% received industry recognition, 45% said it helped them leverage a promotion or pay raise, and 15% reported that it helped them get a new job. 18% reported that it benefitted them in another way, such as getting into graduate school or expanding their current role at their place of employment.

In an effort to attract more students to the PIPED program and to encourage more high school students to pursue degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), CCSF partnered with the San Francisco Unified School District’s International Studies Academy to offer dual credit courses. A CCSF faculty paired with a Career Technical Education high school teacher to develop a new curriculum, lesson plans, and teach the class. A total of 13 students earned dual credit over two semesters. In the fall of 2015, when surveyed, 88% of the students said that the engineering projects in the class increased their interest in going to college in a field related to STEM “very much” or “quite a bit.”
